SubTopics: Fluently divide multi-digit numbers using the standard algorithm.
Content: What is the value of 63,798 ÷ 49?

SubTopics: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.
Content: What is the value of the following expression?

SubTopics: Understand the absolute value of a rational number as its distance from 0 on the number line; interpret absolute value as magnitude for a positive or negative quantity in a real-world situation.
Content: Points A, B, C, and D are plotted on the number line shown.
problems/MDG6M/media/3a.jpg
Which point represents the value of |3|?

SubTopics: Write an inequality of the form x > c or x < c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.
Content: All of the numbers that do not exceed 15 will be graphed on a number line.
Which statement best describes the graph of the numbers?

A.Choice: The graph will be a ray that starts at 14 and points to the left. The graph will include the endpoint of the ray.

B.Choice: The graph will be a ray that starts at 15 and points to the left. The graph will include the endpoint of the ray.

C.Choice: The graph will be a ray that starts at 15 and points to the right. The graph will not include the endpoint of the ray.

D.Choice: The graph will be a ray that starts at 16 and points to the left. The graph will not include the endpoint of the ray.

SubTopics: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm for each operation.
Content: What is the value of 25.761 - 17.49?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.
Content: Melvin and Roberto played football on two different teams last season.

:ibox:• Melvin's team won w games.

• Roberto's team won 3 fewer games than Melvin's team.
Which expression can be used to represent the number of games Roberto's team won last season?

SubTopics: Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language to describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.
Content: A jar contains some marbles that are either white or red. The ratio of the number of white marbles to the number of red marbles is 2:3.
What might be the total amount of white and red marbles in the jar?
Select all ALL apply.

SubTopics: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: An artist is creating several pieces of pottery.

:ibox:• He has 10 4/5 pounds of clay.

• He will use 7/10 of a pound to create each piece of pottery.
What is the GREATEST number of pieces of pottery the artist can make with this clay?

A.Choice: The artist can create 3 pieces of pottery.

B.Choice: The artist can create 5 pieces of pottery.

C.Choice: The artist can create 12 pieces of pottery.

D.Choice: The artist can create 15 pieces of pottery.

SubTopics: Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1-100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.
Content: An expression is shown.
Which expression is equivalent to the given expression AND is written using the GREATEST common factor of the two numbers in the expression?

SubTopics: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them).
Content: Which expressions are equivalent to 4x + 16?
Select ALL that apply.

SubTopics: Find and position integers and other rational numbers on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram; find and position pairs of integers and other rational numbers on a coordinate plane.
Content: Describe how the numbers -7 1/2 and -7 would be positioned relative to each other on a horizontal number line.

A.Choice: The number -7 1/2 would be positioned to the left of 7- on a horizontal number line because -7 1/2 < -7.

B.Choice: The number -7 1/2 would be positioned to the left of 7- on a horizontal number line because -7 1/2 > -7.

C.Choice: The number -7 1/2 would be positioned to the right of 7- on a horizontal number line because -7 1/2 < -7.

D.Choice: The number -7 1/2 would be positioned to the right of 7- on a horizontal number line because -7 1/2 > -7.

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.
Content: Point A is located at (6, 3) in the coordinate plane. Point B is located 5 units below point A.
problems/MDG6M/media/12a.jpg
Which quadrant in the coordinate plane contains point B?

SubTopics: Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.
Content: Which of the following histograms shows a distribution that is skewed to the left?

SubTopics: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm for each operation.
Content: What is the value of 43.7 × 0.25?

SubTopics: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.
Content: Which value from the set {3/4, 1, 3/2, 3 3/4} is a solution to the equation x + 3/2 = 2 1/4?

SubTopics: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = lwh and V = Bh to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Kevin has a rectangular prism that was made up of identical cubes, with no gaps between any cubes. The following figure shows the prism and one of the cubes.
problems/MDG6M/media/16a.jpg
What was the total number of the cubes used to make up the prism?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
Content: A baker made 8 pounds of cookie dough. The baker used the dough to make several batches of cookies. The graph shows the amount of cookie dough that is needed to make different numbers of batches of cookies.
problems/MDG6M/media/17a.jpg
Based on the graph, which statement correctly explains the number of batches of cookies the baker can make from the 8 pounds of dough?

A.Choice: The baker can make 8 batches of cookies because it takes 1 pound of dough to make 1 batch of cookies.

B.Choice: The baker can make 16 batches of cookies because it takes 1 pound of dough to make 1 batch of cookies.

C.Choice: The baker can make 8 batches of cookies because it takes 1 pound of dough to make 2 batches of cookies.

D.Choice: The baker can make 16 batches of cookies because it takes 1 pound of dough to make 2 batches of cookies.

SubTopics: Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.
Content: A machine in a factory makes chairs at a rate of 2 chairs every 10 minutes.

:ibox:• How much time does the machine take to make 5 chairs?

• How many minutes would it take for the factory to fulfill an order for 32 chairs?
Show your work or explain how you determined your answers.
Time for 5 chairs: :FR-1:
Time for 32 chairs: :FR-2:

SubTopics: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
Content: A worker has 25 feet of ribbon to make bows. Each bow uses 2 feet of ribbon. The worker divides 25 by 2 and gets 12.5 as an answer.
What does the worker's answer mean in this context?

A.Choice: The worker can make 12 bows and have 1 foot of ribbon left.

B.Choice: The worker can make 12 bows and have 5 feet of ribbon left.

C.Choice: The worker can make 5 bows and have 12 feet of ribbon left.

D.Choice: The worker can make 1 bow and have 12 feet of ribbon left.

SubTopics: Distinguish comparisons of absolute value from statements about order.
Content: The numbers -1/2 and 2/5 are graphed on the number line.
problems/MDG6M/media/20a.jpg
Which statement correctly compares the absolute values of -1/2 and 2/5 and gives the correct reasoning for the comparison?

A.Choice: -1/2 has the lesser absolute value because -1/2 is closer to zero than 2/5 is to zero.

B.Choice: -1/2 has the greater absolute value because -1/2 is closer to zero than 2/5 is to zero.

C.Choice: -1/2 has the lesser absolute value because -1/2 is further to zero than 2/5 is to zero.

D.Choice: -1/2 has the greater absolute value because -1/2 is further to zero than 2/5 is to zero.

SubTopics: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Content: At a store, 40% of all the refrigerators are silver. There are 50 silver refrigerators at the store.
How many refrigerators are at the store?

SubTopics: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Content: Laura uses 3 yards of fabric to make 2 skirts. She uses the same amount of fabric to make each skirt.
At this rate, what is the total amount of fabric, in yards, she needs to make 6 skirts?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
Content: Packages of bottled water are purchased for a sixth-grade picnic. Each package contains 24 water bottles.
Which graph models the relationship between x, the number of packages of bottled water purchased, and y, the number of water bottles?

SubTopics: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = lwh and V = Bh to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: The diagram shows the net of a wooden chest in the shape of a rectangular prism. All dimensions are in feet.
problems/MDG6M/media/24a.jpg
A painter will apply stain to all the faces of the wooden chest. The calculations that the painter used to find the surface area, in square feet, of the wooden chest are shown.
The total surface area is 12 1/2 + 16 1/2 + 24 1/2 = 53 1/2 square feet.

:ibox:• Find the correct surface area of the wooden chest.

• Explain what mistake was made in the calculation of the surface area of the wooden chest.

SubTopics: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
Content: The expression 12x + 8 is equivalent to the expression a(bx + c), where b and c are constants and have no common factors. A student wrote the answer as 2(6x + 4).
Which statement BEST explains whether the student's answer is correct or incorrect?

A.Choice: The student's answer is incorrect because the greatest common factor of 12x and 8 is 2x, so the correct expression is 2x(6x + 4).

B.Choice: The student's answer is incorrect because the greatest common factor of 12x and 8 is 4x, so the correct expression is 4x(3x + 2).

C.Choice: The student's answer is incorrect because the greatest common factor of 12x and 8 is 4, so the correct expression is 4(3x + 2).

D.Choice: The student's answer is incorrect because the greatest common factor of 12x and 8 is 8, so the correct expression is 8(4x + 1).

SubTopics: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: An art teacher has a jar containing 3/4 pound of glitter for use by the students in a class. The glitter is being separated into portions that are each 1/10 pound of glitter.
The teacher asked, “What is the greatest number of whole portions that can be made?”
One student incorrectly obtains the answer of 4/3 × 10/1 =40/3 = 13 1/3, and says 13 portions can be made.

:ibox:• What is the correct answer to the question?

• Explain the mistake that was made in the calculations.

SubTopics: Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.
Content: Students in a science class measured rain by writing down the depth of water in a bucket that collected the rain. The bucket was empty before the rain began to fall at a steady rate over a 6-hour period during school. After 3 hours, the water had a depth of 18 millimeters.
At what average unit rate, in millimeters per hour, did the bucket fill after rain started to fall at a steady rate?

SubTopics: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context.
Content: The following histogram summarizes the recorded number of push-ups that a group of fitness instructors completed in a certain time period. Each interval contains possible values at the left endpoint up to but not including the right endpoint.
problems/MDG6M/media/28a.jpg
What is the total number of fitness instructors represented in the histogram who completed 57 or more push-ups?

SubTopics: Write expressions that record operations with numbers and with letters standing for numbers.
Content: Yvonne's age, in years, is represented by y. Rebekah's age is one year less than three times Yvonne's age.
Which expression represents Rebekah's age, in years?

SubTopics: Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given coordinates for the vertices; use coordinates to find the length of a side joining points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Point K is located at (1, 2) on the following coordinate plane. A square that has a perimeter of 20 units will be drawn so that K is one vertex of the square.
problems/MDG6M/media/30a.jpg
Which THREE ordered pairs could represent the location of another vertex of the square?

SubTopics: Make tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole-number measurements, find missing values in the tables, and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.
Content: The table shows several values of `x` and `y`.
problems/MDG6M/media/31a.jpg
A student claims that since each value for y is 5 more than the corresponding value of x, that the ratio of y to x is 5 to 1 for the values in the tables.
Which statement BEST explains whether the student's claim is correct or incorrect?

A.Choice: The student's claim is correct because 6 - 1 = 5, 8 - 3 = 5, and 9 - 4 = 5

B.Choice: The student's claim is incorrect because the ratio of y to x is different for each pair of corresponding x- and y-values.

C.Choice: The student's claim is incorrect because the ratio of y to x is 1 to 5 for each pair of corresponding x- and y-values.

D.Choice: The student's claim is incorrect because the ratio between the x-values and the y-values of the first two points is 2 to 1 and not 5 to 1.

SubTopics: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.
Content: Many frames are being made to hold a number of paintings that all have a width of 18 inches. The wood being used to make the frames is 2 inches wide.
problems/MDG6M/media/32a.jpg
If the height of one of the paintings was 24 inches, what is the total length, in inches, of 2-inch wood that would be needed to make the frame? Show your work and your calculations.
What is the number of square inches of wood that a frame would have if the painting had a height of 36 inches?

SubTopics: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.
Content: The equation x + 5 = 12 can be solved using one step.
Which statement provides a correct explanation and solution to the equation?

A.Choice: The number 5 should be added to both sides of the equation, and the solution is x = 17.

B.Choice: The number 5 should be subtracted from both sides of the equation, and the solution is x = 7.

C.Choice: The number 5 should be divided from both sides of the equation, and the solution is x = 12/5.

D.Choice: The number 5 should be multiplied to both sides of the equation, and the solution is x = 60.

SubTopics: Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.
Content: A machine at a company makes toy cars at a constant rate. The company received an order for toy cars that exceeded the number of toy cars that the company had in stock.
Which THREE pieces of information are needed to determine the amount of time it will take the machine to make enough additional toy cars to fill the order?

A.Choice: the cost to make each toy car

B.Choice: the rate that the machine makes toy cars

C.Choice: the number of toy cars requested in the order

D.Choice: the number of people needed to run the machine

E.Choice: the number of toy cars available when the order was received

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
Content: A game designer used 9 ounces of clay to make 24 identical pieces for a game.
What is the number of ounces of clay that were used for each piece?
